Sx1.30.table:
g𝑔g VPP index
G𝐺G Set of VPPs in the system
NGsubscript𝑁𝐺N_{G} Number of VPPs
Cgg​2​c​(Pg)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑔𝑔2𝑐subscript𝑃𝑔C_{g}^{g2c}(P_{g}) Electricity cost of exporting electricity from VPP g𝑔g to the community
Cgc​2​g​(Pg)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑔𝑐2𝑔subscript𝑃𝑔C_{g}^{c2g}(P_{g}) Electricity cost of exporting electricity from the community to VPP g𝑔g
c1,gg​2​csuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝑔𝑔2𝑐c_{1,g}^{g2c}, c2,gg​2​csuperscriptsubscript𝑐2𝑔𝑔2𝑐c_{2,g}^{g2c} Cost function parameters for VPP g𝑔g to export electricity to the community
c1,gc​2​gsuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝑔𝑐2𝑔c_{1,g}^{c2g}, c2,gc​2​gsuperscriptsubscript𝑐2𝑔𝑐2𝑔c_{2,g}^{c2g} Cost function parameters for the community to export electricity to VPP g𝑔g
Pgsubscript𝑃𝑔P_{g} Power net demand of VPP g𝑔g
Pg∗superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑔P_{g}^{*} Power net demand of VPP g𝑔g at optimal solution
Pc​o​m​m​u​n​i​t​ysubscript𝑃𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑚𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡𝑦P_{community} Net demand of the community

Pg,c​2​g¯¯subscript𝑃𝑔𝑐2𝑔\overline{P_{g,c2g}} The maximum possible power from the community that VPP g𝑔g can consume

Pgtsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑔𝑡P_{g}^{t} Power net generation of VPP g𝑔g at iteration t𝑡t

references:
Characterized by numerous decentralized and autonomous buildings, a TEC is suitable for the structure of a multi-user (agent) system.
Multi-user (agent) paradigms lend themselves well to managing and orchestrating a diverse set of autonomous buildings of a TEC.
In this setup, each user (agent) can execute local computations and engage in communication 2.
Multi-agent optimization techniques create a collaborative framework where agents collectively solve problems (e.g., maximizing self-consumption) by utilizing local computational resources and communication networks
3.
In this paper, we utilize a Consensus + Innovations approach 4 to regulate the collaboration between members of a TEC.
In this approach, the Consensus term enforces an agreement between agents, while the Innovations term guides local constraints fulfillment.
Local constraints are associated with the local buildings’ net demand, which requires an accurate forecast 4, and FL can address this need.

FL’s architecture allows a collaborative and privacy-preserving training of Machine Learning (ML) models. In the TEC context, FL allows the use of private data, like the number of users in the building, to achieve more accurate forecast models. Additionally, collaboration enables ML models to gain more adaptivity, making the accuracy levels more stable. For example, in new TECs, where the buildings can have insufficient samples, it is possible to take advantage of a pre-trained ML model by a TEC that has been using a FL framework.

Each TEC building, b𝑏b, has two independent systems: demand forecaster and a forecast system for local PV generation. Both systems use the same ML architecture, represented in Table 1, which uses two Long-Short Term Models (LSTM), with the ReLu as an activation function, and two dropout layers.

The setup for the initialization of the selected FL framework includes their parameters and the LSTM local hyperparameters.
The implemented scenario is constituted of community a𝑎a (100 buildings) and community b𝑏b (25 buildings).
All the 125125125 buildings have a PV system installed. The selected FL framework allows training the forecast models independent from the selected system, i.e., in an FL round ℛℛ\mathcal{R} a building with PV can be selected for training its forecast system of demand, but this not imply that its generation forecast model is also selected for training. Therefore, two independent parameterizations are needed, one for each system. For the global parameters of the FL architecture, behind the number of rounds, the number of participants in each round 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} needs to be defined. For the LSTM models, seven hyperparameters are needed: (i) local epochs e𝑒e; (ii) batch size bssubscript𝑏𝑠b_{s}; (iii) validation split vssubscript𝑣𝑠v_{s}; (iv) past observation posubscript𝑝𝑜p_{o}; (v) future observations to be predicted fosubscript𝑓𝑜f_{o}; (vi) number of cells in input layer ci​lsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑙c_{il}; and (vii) the number of cells in the hidden layers ch​lsubscript𝑐ℎ𝑙c_{hl}. Table 2 presents the used parameters. It was defined that both systems will have the same configuration, only differing when it is community a𝑎a or community b𝑏b. Additionally, to ensure fair comparison LSTM parameters are kept the same for the FL and the baseline model.

The forecast results are presented in Table 3.
In this table, F refers to the framework (FLF or LMF), and M indicates the selected month for test or train/test (from the community of 25 buildings). Additionally, the forecasted system (demand (d)/generation (g)) is shown as S. The number of community buildings is presented as C.
Based on the obtained results, FLF achieves better performance across all tests. However, as the number of test data points increases, the gap between LMF and FLF results narrows.
Another observation is that the difference between FLF and LMF is higher in the community with 25 buildings. This happens because FLF has the advantage of using a model pre-trained by the community with 100 buildings.

The gap between (i) the actual optimal energy price and (ii) the agreement among local copies of energy prices (the consensus value) for two communities, and by using three different net demand forecast methods are depicted in Figures 9-14.
Additionally, the cumulative energy price difference over a day, as calculated by (24), is numerically presented in Table 4.
A lower total energy price difference denotes a more precise energy price computation and superior performance.
Notably, the Real Net Demand (RND) method demonstrates the least deviation in energy price compared to the true optimal value (λτ∗superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜏\lambda_{\tau}^{*}).

Table 4 shows a reduced price deviation when contrasting the FLF with the LMF, indicating its superiority.
In specific instances, the price difference for FLF achieves up to 1.36 times greater accuracy than LMF in April for community a𝑎a and up to 8 times better accuracy in August for community b𝑏b.
Figures 7 and 7 have shown that FLF exhibits less forecast error than LMF.
This analysis confirms that net demand forecasting accuracy is a pivotal factor influencing the Consensus + Innovations approach’s performance.
Minimizing forecast errors reduces the distributed optimization error and enhances the proposed system’s reliability.
Conversely, a high forecast error can misguide the Consensus + Innovations updates towards erroneous values.

A comparative assessment of communities a𝑎a and b𝑏b yields additional insights. The community a𝑎a, with its extensive data repository, effectively trains both the FL and local models.
In contrast, community b𝑏b possesses limited data samples, impacting model training.
As Table 4 suggests, the performance discrepancy between the FL and local models is more pronounced in the community b𝑏b than in a𝑎a.
This indicates that the FL-assisted Consensus + Innovations approach is proficient at model transfer to similar systems with less historical data.

The results in Figure 9 also distinguish two error types: those from net demand forecasting and the inherent errors of the distributed iterative approach, that is the Consensus + Innovations Approach.
Systems with an unknown net demand (FLF and LMF) are susceptible to forecasting and distributed estimation errors.
In contrast, known net demand scenarios (RND) predominantly face errors from the distributed iterative approach, as evidenced by the blue curve in Fig. 9.
These distributed estimation errors can be mitigated through finely-tuned hyperparameters (e.g., α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta in (15)).
Furthermore, the magnitude of distributed estimation error appears more noticeable in larger communities.
Comparing the total energy price differences for RND between communities a𝑎a and b𝑏b in Table 4, community a𝑎a exhibits a higher error, attributable to its larger building count compared to community b𝑏b.

In this table, F refers to the framework (FLF or LMF), and M indicates the selected month for test or train/test (from the community of 25 buildings). Additionally, the forecasted system (demand (d)/generation (g)) is shown as S. The number of community buildings is presented as C.

The gap between (i) the actual optimal energy price and (ii) the agreement among local copies of energy prices (the consensus value) for two communities, and by using three different net demand forecast methods are depicted in Figures 9-14.
Additionally, the cumulative energy price difference over a day, as calculated by (24), is numerically presented in Table 4.
A lower total energy price difference denotes a more precise energy price computation and superior performance.
Notably, the Real Net Demand (RND) method demonstrates the least deviation in energy price compared to the true optimal value (λτ∗superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜏\lambda_{\tau}^{*}).

Table 4 shows a reduced price deviation when contrasting the FLF with the LMF, indicating its superiority.
In specific instances, the price difference for FLF achieves up to 1.36 times greater accuracy than LMF in April for community a𝑎a and up to 8 times better accuracy in August for community b𝑏b.
Figures 7 and 7 have shown that FLF exhibits less forecast error than LMF.
This analysis confirms that net demand forecasting accuracy is a pivotal factor influencing the Consensus + Innovations approach’s performance.
Minimizing forecast errors reduces the distributed optimization error and enhances the proposed system’s reliability.
Conversely, a high forecast error can misguide the Consensus + Innovations updates towards erroneous values.

A comparative assessment of communities a𝑎a and b𝑏b yields additional insights. The community a𝑎a, with its extensive data repository, effectively trains both the FL and local models.
In contrast, community b𝑏b possesses limited data samples, impacting model training.
As Table 4 suggests, the performance discrepancy between the FL and local models is more pronounced in the community b𝑏b than in a𝑎a.
This indicates that the FL-assisted Consensus + Innovations approach is proficient at model transfer to similar systems with less historical data.

The results in Figure 9 also distinguish two error types: those from net demand forecasting and the inherent errors of the distributed iterative approach, that is the Consensus + Innovations Approach.
Systems with an unknown net demand (FLF and LMF) are susceptible to forecasting and distributed estimation errors.
In contrast, known net demand scenarios (RND) predominantly face errors from the distributed iterative approach, as evidenced by the blue curve in Fig. 9.
These distributed estimation errors can be mitigated through finely-tuned hyperparameters (e.g., α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta in (15)).
Furthermore, the magnitude of distributed estimation error appears more noticeable in larger communities.
Comparing the total energy price differences for RND between communities a𝑎a and b𝑏b in Table 4, community a𝑎a exhibits a higher error, attributable to its larger building count compared to community b𝑏b.
